awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Blending Ecology and Evolution using Emerging Technologies to Determine Species Distributions with a Non-native Pathogen in a Changing Climate
awd_abstract_narration:
Predicting future distributions of plants on Earth is an urgent and daunting challenge, given the combined effects of climate change and invasive species, along with the fact that science does not fully understand how ecological and evolutionary processes interact across large areas. Southwestern white pine (SWP), a tree that occurs naturally from northern Arizona through central Mexico, is the focus of this project. Understanding its future depends on understanding biological processes at the molecular level, including the movement of genes, adaptations to disease and drought, and other heritable changes, interact in a changing environment interact to govern its overall success. But in addition, sustainability of SWP is threatened by a non-native tree disease called white pine blister rust. This project will develop tools to help forecast and manage the future of SWP, including genomic analyses, common garden trials where seedlings originating from different environments are planted together, screening for disease resistance, engineering and technology innovation to measure drought tolerance, and computer modeling that can integrate landscape ecology and genomics. The approach will also provide a prototype for forecasting complex system behavior that is more generally applicable.

The results of this project will contribute to the conservation of SWP and the ecosystems in which it occurs. White pine blister rust causes widespread tree decline and mortality in western North America, including the rapidly expanding area where it overlaps with SWP. It is quite possible that the climate will change too rapidly for SWP to adapt, causing widespread tree death and potential extinction. To help reach its goals, this project will also involve a number of educational and outreach activities, including exhibits and real common garden plantings at Flagstaff Arboretum in Arizona and the U.S. Forest Service Dorena Genetic Resource Center in Cottage Grove, Oregon. A number of postdoctoral scholars and graduate and undergraduate students will be trained and participate in interdisciplinary science that bridges genomics, tree disease resistance testing, landscape ecology, modeling, engineering, remote sensing, and spatial analysis. An outreach website and content will be developed in English and Spanish to provide results to the public, including land managers. Postdoctoral researchers will collaborate on a workshop for students in Mexico as part of their training. Workshops will also be developed for conferences in the Southwest, one of which will be a major cross-border meeting between Mexican and U.S. foresters. In short, this project will strengthen cross-border research, management efforts in forest conservation, and our understanding of how genetics shape life on Earth.

por.por_cntn:
Southwestern white pine (SWWP; Pinus strobiformis) is an important tree species of the southwestern US and Mexico. Southwestern white pine populations are threatened by climate change and a non-native,  invasive tree disease, white pine blister rust (caused by the fungal pathogen, Cronartium ribicola). Climate change is negatively affecting SWWP by increasing heat and drought stress, and thus challenging its ability to adapt. White pine blister rust causes extensive tree decline and mortality in SWWP and can negatively impact regeneration in SWWP. The dual threats of climate change and invasive species make forecasting future tree distributions at continental scales an urgent challenge. The goal of our project was to determine how gene movement among populations, adaptation to disease and drought, heritable changes beyond DNA mutations, and a changing environment interact to govern the success of SWWP.

We have developed tools to help forecast and manage the future of the species, including those from genomics, ecophysiology, common gardens, tree disease resistance testing, and remote sensing to measure drought tolerance, disease resistance and presence and physiological response.

Our major findings and developments are:

  1. In the US Southwest, Pinus strobiformis and Pinus flexilis hybridize frequently, forming a large hybrid zone; that zone that is moving north on evolutionary time scales
  2. Climate envelope models predict range contractions in Mexico, range expansions in the hybrid zone and north
  3. Genetic adaptations to climate conditions from different source populations:
    1. Evidence for seedling plasticity in water use efficiency under warmer conditions
    2. Seed moved and grown too far north results in high mortality, even within the range of the species
    3. Phenological (bud burst in spring and bud set in fall) differences related to cold damage and mortality
    4. Effects of experimental warming of developing seed on resulting seedling performance was not long-term
  4. Range-wide frequency and patterns of genetic resistance to white pine blister rust: we identified individual trees with major gene resistance and others with relatively high levels of quantitative disease resistance across the species? range; seed can be collected from these for both gene conservation and reforestation
  5. An automated hyperspectral imaging platform was developed to identify the pre-visual presences of infected seedlings and the progression of the disease through time. The Normalized Photochemical Reflectance Index (PRIn) was identified as an appropriate index to track the progression of the disease in a greenhouse setting. The platform is being scaled up to large scale screening trials at DGRC.

Our findings and developments have implications for management of not only SWWP but can serve as a model for managing species facing both invasive tree diseases and the increasing impacts of climate change. Preserving a wide genetic base both in situ (in natural forests) while collecting seed for genetic conservation ex situ (in gene banks) will be needed to conserve genes associated with adaptive traits. Such strategies need to include the range margins and individual trees identified with ?special? traits such as genetic resistance to disease. Furthermore, managers should be aware that trees with traits to handle aridity and cold may grow more slowly. Reforestation decisions should include the avoidance of large geographic movements of seed north while also considering genetic disease resistance and climate adaptations in the source population. Silvicultural treatments, including tree density reductions and prescribed fire, may be necessary to protect both individual trees and entire populations.

We disseminated the results of our project through the peer-reviewed literature (23 papers to date) and conference presentations at local, regional, national and international conferences (>50). These included preparing a special conference session focused on using SWWP as a model species for cross-scale research. We also prepared and delivered a workshop in Mexico related to use of technology for project management and genomics. We delivered posters and presentations in Spanish and disseminated information about the symptoms of white pine blister rust disease to Mexican foresters to enable them to identify the disease if they encounter it in Mexico (where we do not believe it is yet established). Two postdoctoral scholars, three M.S. students and two Ph.D. students were trained through this project, along with numerous undergraduates. We supported a diversity of students and volunteers, including females, retirees and under-represented minorities. Tribal members of the Din? Nation supported including two undergraduate students and one teacher. Three graduate students from Mexico completed summer internships working on the project in Oregon and Arizona.
